title: For Trade:  Berkeley County seizing weapons from vehicle
postcontent:
I have brought this up again because it is time for elections in Berkeley County and the Sheirff's office is at stake. Know your rights when it comes to legally storing your weapon in your vehicles according to state law and while carrying/ or not with your valid CWP.
1) State Law prohibits local municipalities from taking your weapon from your vehicle.
"Officer safety" is satisfied when you are standing outside your vehicle or seperated from your weapon. 
2) Officers cannot seize your property unless you are under arrest.
SC code section 23-31-520
This article denies any county, municipality, or political subdivision the power to confiscate a firearm or ammunition unless incident to an arrest. 
If you are being arrested and your car is being impounded they can seize the weapons in your vehicle. That's it.
3) If you are a CWP holder and your gun is not on your person, you do not have to present your CWP in a traffic stop. This has been mistaught in many CWP classes. If your gun is stored legally in accordance with state then you are not carrying a concealed weapon. This has been corrected my CWP instructor and was verified with the SLED head of CWP program.
Funny. I will probably still show mine. Just seems like a nice thing to do. Never had any issues in other municipalities.
4) See MIchigan v. Long, 103 S. Ct. 3469 (1983)
Search the above court ruling to read where they denied the right to search for and seize weapons for "officer safety"unless certain criteria were met. Namely the officer has to consider you dangerous and believe that there is a reasonable chance that you can get away from him and back into your vehicle to get your weapon, if there is a weapon.
I wasn't even so much as patted down even after presenting a cwp so the officer certainly wasn't afraid as he turned his back on me to enter my vehicle with me directly behind him.
Since I did not pose a threat to the officer and I was not under arrest, he can not enter my truck and confiscate my property.
Three lawyers agreed that my civil rights were violated but there was no financial loss substantial enough for them to sue unless I shelled out cash. And honestly, I am not the sueing type. I just don't want bad cops, or bad departments with "unspoken or unwritten policies" patrolling Berkeley County or anywhere else I may roam.
I kept an arrest journal of every contact I had with the officer and his supervisor. I will gladly share the information with you. The supervisors comments are the most shocking, especially when posed a question about entering my house. I have asked for recordings of all of the interactions but was told none of them were recorded. The stop was not recorded either but I recorded the second half.
I contacted Sheriff DeWitt about this and spoke with him twice. I can only assume that his inaction on this matter means 1) he supports the actions taken, 2) made this unspoken policy, or 3) has no control over his department.
This interaction coupled with statements made by DeWitt after Sandy Hook leads me to the conclusion that our Sheirff and his department's philosophy on gun control when dealing with law abiding citizens does not match that of his constituents. 
What do you think? Have you kept up with the frequent mishandling of gun control issues across the country by local municipalities and the militarization of local enforcement agencies with federal monies? We need a pro-2nd ammendment sheriff who will see to it that his deputies operate in accordance with state law and the mandates of the Supreme Court. It is election time. This is an important election at an important time.

FYI-
I have MANY friends in law enforcement and all agree with my position on this. Not one offered an argument in favor of the officer or supervisor especially after learning that 1) the officer did not check me for weapons after presenting a card saying that I have one on my person 2) knowing that I am 235lbs of scary looking redneck and the officer turned his back on me while I hovered over his shoulder 3) The officers unfamiliarity with my SERPA holster leading to him repeatedly (and laughably) yanking on a loaded weapon.
Number one comment from cop buddies(and gun buddies) is officers are not trained on how to operate every firearm system and it is unreasonable to assume that they can all clear every weapon without incident. Many guns can be stored in vehicles and they can all function differently or even malfunction because of miscare by the owner and officers take a risk in handling unknown weapons. 
Ever tried to check a Phoenix HP-22 to see if it is loaded(total pain in the ass)? Ever pulled a slide back and have an unintended discharge due to a broken firing pin? Ever seen a cop mishandle a weapon and shoot himself in the foot (youtube)? Ever seen anyone accidentally shot while standing next to someone who is trained in firearms mishandling a weapon?

After my last post I received numerous emails with the same story. One from Richland County as well but his weapon was concealed on his person. 
Think about it folks... Can your local cops take your guns from your home if they see them while checking a complaint about dogs barking? NO but I had a BCSD supervisor tell me yes. Can BCSD seize a weapon from your vehicle that is stored lin accordance with state law during a routine traffic stop? State law says NO, but it happens and is apparently supported even though I was repeatedly told that IT WAS NOT A WRITTEN POLICY.  Officer safety is satisfied when you are outside your vehicle away from your gun. Hell, I haven't been seperated from my gun or asked to exit the vehicle in two stops with Goose Creek PD and one with Moncks Corner. (tail light malfunction, I am not a regular offender, Truck's getting old)
This is the wrong time to have this kind of law enforcement mentality.
This is a second and fourth ammendment issue right here in Berkeley County.
This isn't something going on in Nevada or New York. Call your neighbors with the Gadsden Flag on their house and the DeWitt sign in their yeard and let them know they are quite mistaken about his policies, and perhaps character.
